name: Skill Catalog
title: Skill Catalog
description: Registry of skill types available for agent building. Contains metadata and descriptions - implementations are stack-specific.

axiomAlignment.A1_verifiability: Skill catalog enables verification of agent-skill alignment
axiomAlignment.A2_user_primacy: Skill selection supports user goals and agent capabilities
axiomAlignment.A3_transparency: Explicit skill metadata makes capabilities traceable
axiomAlignment.A4_non_harm: Stack and dependency validation prevent incorrect skill assignment
axiomAlignment.A5_consistency: Unified skill structure across categories and stacks

usage.forFactory: Use factoryPattern path to find the implementation template
usage.forStackSpecific: Skills with factoryPattern: null are implemented in the respective implementationRepo
usage.blueprintReference: Blueprints can reference any skill by id - factory generates from pattern or documents as requirement

skill_selection.description: Select skills based on agent purpose, stack compatibility, and required capabilities
skill_selection.usage: Query skills.{skill_id} to check stackAgnostic flag, targetStack, and whenToUse guidance
skill_selection.use_when: Query skills.{skill_id} to check stackAgnostic flag, targetStack, and whenToUse guidance
skill_selection.code_example:
skill = next((s for s in skills if s["id"] == skill_id and 
    stack in s.get("targetStack", [])), None)
best_practices: Document the pattern usage and rationale in code comments
Validate implementation against domain requirements before deployment

skill_composition.description: Compose multiple skills to build complex agent capabilities without duplicating logic
skill_composition.usage: Reference skills.{skill_id}.requiresSkills or complementsSkill to understand skill relationships
skill_composition.use_when: Reference skills.{skill_id}.requiresSkills or complementsSkill to understand skill relationships
skill_composition.code_example:
# Implement skill_composition per skill-catalog patterns
# See description and related documentation
best_practices: Document the pattern usage and rationale in code comments
Validate implementation against domain requirements before deployment

category_filtering.description: Filter skills by category (core, workflow, testing, etc.) to find relevant capabilities quickly
category_filtering.usage: Use categories.{category} to understand skill groupings, then query skillsByStack for stack-specific lists
category_filtering.use_when: Use categories.{category} to understand skill groupings, then query skillsByStack for stack-specific lists
category_filtering.code_example:
# Implement category_filtering per skill-catalog patterns
# See description and related documentation
best_practices: Document the pattern usage and rationale in code comments
Validate implementation against domain requirements before deployment

factory_vs_project.description: Distinguish between Factory-provided skills (factoryPattern exists) and project-specific implementations
factory_vs_project.usage: Check factoryPattern field: if null, skill is implemented in external repo; if path exists, Factory provides template
factory_vs_project.use_when: Check factoryPattern field: if null, skill is implemented in external repo; if path exists, Factory provides template
factory_vs_project.code_example:
# Implement factory_vs_project per skill-catalog patterns
# See description and related documentation
best_practices: Document the pattern usage and rationale in code comments
Validate implementation against domain requirements before deployment
Select stack-agnostic skills when possible to maximize reusability across different technology stacks
Check skill dependencies (requiresSkills) before assigning to agents to ensure all prerequisites are available
Use skill categories to discover related capabilities - skills in the same category often work well together
Reference factoryPattern paths when implementing Factory-provided skills to maintain consistency with Factory standards
Document custom project-specific skills in skill-catalog.json with clear whenToUse guidance for future reference
Validate that targetStack matches your project stack before using stack-specific skills to avoid compatibility issues
Compose multiple focused skills rather than creating monolithic skills that violate single responsibility principle
Keep skill-catalog.json synchronized with actual skill implementations - update when skills are added, removed, or modified

anti_patterns.name: Skill Stack Mismatch
anti_patterns.problem: Assigning stack-specific skills (e.g., sap-grounding) to agents in incompatible stacks causes runtime failures
anti_patterns.fix: Always check targetStack field before assigning skills. Use stack-agnostic alternatives when available

anti_patterns.name: Missing Skill Dependencies
anti_patterns.problem: Using skills that require other skills (requiresSkills) without including dependencies breaks agent functionality
anti_patterns.fix: Check requiresSkills field and include all dependencies when assigning skills to agents

anti_patterns.name: Duplicate Skill Implementations
anti_patterns.problem: Creating project-specific versions of Factory-provided skills instead of using factoryPattern templates
anti_patterns.fix: Use factoryPattern paths to generate skill implementations. Only create custom skills for truly unique requirements

anti_patterns.name: Orphaned Skill References
anti_patterns.problem: Referencing skills in agents or blueprints that don't exist in skill-catalog.json breaks validation and discovery
anti_patterns.fix: Always add new skills to skill-catalog.json before referencing them. Use catalog as single source of truth

anti_patterns.name: Category Misclassification
anti_patterns.problem: Placing skills in wrong categories makes discovery difficult and breaks category-based filtering
anti_patterns.fix: Follow existing category definitions. When in doubt, use 'core' for generic skills, 'workflow' for process skills
